comment_text:
Our Social Media Platforms are under attack. Twitter is being hit with systematic external attacks in the form of meta-manipulation and inauthentic users who attempt to shape the discussion by slowly and methodically radicalizing people. These attackers have demonstrated the desire to promote tribalism and the "us" vs "them" mentality. I propose proactive unity as a countermeasure.

It's kind of interesting how crazy typing a sentence like that makes a person sound... but it's absolutely true.

My twitter accounts are here (open in new tab?):
http://www.smartereveryday.com/twitter
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
For those commenting on Twitter having a political agenda:
I've read the same articles and listened to the same podcast episodes you have on this subject.... and I've concluded that I seem to take a more nuanced perspective on this than others.


Whenever I hear about an individual ban/suspension/censorship, the first thing I do is read about the context of the ban. I then divide them into 2 groups.


*Group 1 Suspensions: Bans based off of Twitter's values and policy decisions. *
In this case it's clear to me a human actively makes a decision to ban someone, or a specific keyword or phrase etc. I agree that several of their policies (banning certain words, phrases, or "protecting" certain groups but not others) should be discussed and debated openly. In case you're not detecting my stance on this I'll spell it out... I have very strong feelings about these things but I'm avoiding disclosing how I feel in order to shine more light on Group 2 suspensions, which are the result of a far more technical threat. Group 1 Suspensions could be changed tomorrow if certain people change their mind.. Group 2 could not.


Group 2 Suspensions. Bans/Suspensions taking place because Twitter is trying to fight literal armies trying to manipulate our society.
I'm finding my attention drawn more to this group more because the attackers' intentions here are so malicious. While doing research for this video, I found that the majority of the inauthentic behavior is focused on content meant to align with the right. This make people on the left think "those people on the right" are more radicalized than reality thus making them retreat further left. Those on the right are also in danger of being pushed further right. The "Us" vs "Them" thinking starts immediately. The play here is subtle, and quite frankly, this is a very intelligent way to attack us. The dataset Twitter released has more right leaning accounts than left. (Look for yourself, here's a spreadsheet URLs to the WayBack machine for each username in that dataset. The Wayback machine didn't image all pages: http://bit.ly/WaybackTrolls ) .One of the interesting problems that Twitter has, is that BECAUSE the majority of the malicious content is built to look like the political viewpoints from one side, they must test their countermeasure algorithms against inauthentic content that also seems to be authentic content on the right. As a result of the target set being unquestionably biased, I would expect disproportionate amount of "collateral damage" flaggings to be on the right.


Whenever I see someone who has been suspended, I try to be intellectually honest and read their complaints and run it through my engineer filter. If they seem emotional, I try to identify what types of emotions are being communicated and use that to figure out what category the ban fits in.


Group 1 Bans are usually pretty clear. These bans are usually a process, not a single event. Still, these victims feel that their speech is being controlled (and by definition it is) so they're usually angry.
Group 2 Bans are often collateral damage, so the sense of injustice is elevated. From what I can tell, Twitter doesn't provide indicate that the suspension was automatic, therefore the user is forced to assume they have crossed some type of ideological barrier and therefore been deemed "not politially correct". The anger in this case usually has a tiny dash of confusion mixed in.


Twitter usually tries to explain that it's a result of automatic filtering.... but without the context of what's going on in this episode, victims of group 2 bans are left to logically assume a political agenda on the part of twitter. They are assume they are the victim of a Group 1 ban. I do not think this is always the case.


Heightened emotions lead Group 2 ban victims to tell as many people about the injustices at Twitter, often as loudly as possible. I've noticed when Twitter is notified (as recently happened with the movie "Unplanned" ) the suspension is reversed immediately, followed by a statement by Twitter explaining that the suspension was the result of an autonomous system. To the victim, this explanation is insufficient, and they continue to think Twitter actually wanted to silence them. In the cases I've read, the victims sometime think that because they yelled loud enough the decision was reversed because they publicly shamed Twitter.


The implications of this are pretty big for Twitter. The result of all this confusion is that the public ends up thinking Twitter's efforts to "control" things are much lager than they actually are. I think it's a good idea for Twitter to be more transparent about this stuff, and Del said they're moving in that direction which is great. For the record, Twitter was 100% open with me and didn't restrict my message in any way.


Because these issues are related to countermeasures, Twitter's sometimes not at liberty to discuss what exactly triggered their system, because knowledge of such systems could lead to exploitation.
I'm personally empathetic because I recognize Twitter is fighting a war.

I've become a big fan of this channel, but I held off for a while watching these videos; I either thought it would be too techy for me to care about, or that it would simply reaffirm my belief that people put too much effort and faith into shady social media platforms.

I'm so glad I was wrong. These videos are much more about human nature than I would have ever guessed. I'd been railing for ages against the idea that people's opinions, especially political ones, have become a way we define who we are, rather than voting just being a task we occasionally do. I really thought the reason why was primarily leadership based; that in an effort to collect votes, politicians would make how you vote become a part of you that you'd emotionally defend. I'm realizing after watching this that, as much as that's still true, it may not even be the main reason. That it's our human nature that hasn't caught up to the tools of our modern world, especially concerning human interaction and socialization, makes a lot of sense.

Here's my worry. Young people are more adept at using any kind of technology, including social media, as they've essentially been around it their whole lives. But they seem to be among the most polarizing on social media. In other words, their human nature isn't evolving toward seeing past divisiveness - it isn't "catching up".

Maybe it's because I'm from the apathetic generation that grew up in the 90s - there was quite literally nothing we cared about, unlike every group that came before and after. So maybe I just wish everyone would chill out just because that's how I am. Even so, the idea that people are so attached to their opinion that they'll fall for any statement of fact that affirms their beliefs, no matter how untrue, is truly alarming.

The problem is that, as the President of the United States, he has a responsibility to make sure - anything - he is endorsing or amplifying is something that is, at the very least, carefully considered. That position comes with a lot of influence, automatically. No different than other powers the President has at his disposal. We have checks and balances for the powers of a President. We currently have none for the President's newfound power of mass media and we are seeing the results of a President using this new power indiscriminately and/or for ill purpose.

In fact, I believe that anyone that has influence needs to carefully consider what they are publishing.

We have entire areas of law (the US Constitution, libel laws, fraud, election campaign laws, etc.) around publishing information, spreading lies, etc. We probably need to create new laws around what you are talking about, laws that extend these laws to the Internet and mass media.

I believe laws, oversight and regulations have definitely NOT kept up with technology. Our reality, everyone having a phone, everyone being tracked, everyone being videoed, the Internet, mass media, etc., etc., has changed in profound ways. Yet, we really haven't kept pace with laws, regulation, oversight (with "teeth" ie investigation/prosecution). And we need to do so.

For example, during the Great Depression, we had bank robbers who were "interstate." As long as they made it out of a certain jurisdiction, they were often free and clear. The FBI was created for this (and other) reasons. It was recognized that this was a new breed of criminal for which current law enforcement was ill-equipped to handle. In fact, it was often lethal for traditional local law enforcement to try and apprehend these new criminals. Thus, we created, or started to create, laws, policies, regulation, oversight, etc. to deal with interstate crime. Europe did something similar with Interpol.

And if I am publishing artificial, or fake news, and YouTube is paying me through monetization? I'm pretty sure that's some kind of fraud. When someone SWAT's someone, that's at least attempted murder as people have died as a consequence of SWAT-ing. But we really don't have laws on the books to deal with these new phenomena (SWAT-ing, Doxing, Internet Harassment, etc.) Look at Wikipedia and all the problems they have, it is like a microcosm for what I am saying.

The laws, gov agencies, regulation of businesses involved in everything the above video is talking about, needs to be updated, created, evolved to account for this. This includes a President (and probably other key gov figures) and how they use mass media, and for what purpose....

I just keep to myself and learn about new things in science, computers, or whatever without worrying about knowing 24/7 whats going on in the world; since in the end does it really matter? I don't associate my identity with politics since that's when things get dangerous.

The argument about RAM storage being volatile is made entirely moot by the fact these things never turn off. It's great that you CAN cut the power to the server and instantly lose all the data, but that's not what's really going on here. Most servers use RAM to handle their data traffic, any drives will be used to store persistent information, like the fact that you're subscribed to their service in the first place. There is authentication, and I can guarantee you that is not being stored in RAM, unless they want to lose all their customers everytime a server loses power.
Here's a fun story: I lost my original Facebook account after having insulted a fictional character as a joke. I never did get that account back despite going through their suspension recovery process and providing them with my driver's license. This is why people get mad about the automated systems, because unless you are someone who matters, you just lose.

I'd say that the biggest problem is when the platform itself has its own agenda. If the big three were absolutely neutral then it would be much easier to spot fraudulent content based upon its extreme nature. But if the platform itself has a perceived bias, then two things happen: 1) genuine content may simply be written off by the viewer as just propaganda being allowed (or even pushed) by the platform, and 2) counter content may be made by gaming the algorithm in an attempt to "level the playing field". If you fix the first problem (addressing platform bias) then these other issues will be much easier to deal with.

Great video! Very informative stuff. However, I still don't think you quite understand how RAM in a VPN works. By logging off of a VPN service you don't query a deletion of the data being stored on RAM. You aren't safe from government monitoring, or anything of the sort. They can be compelled, or even maliciously breached, to reveal important information, including your real IP. Once they know your real IP the jig is up. To be clear this isn't meant to downplay the importance of a VPN. I still think most people would benefit from having one. It's just important to realize that nothing is 100% secure. Not even the infamous Tor network.

Express VPN: so the ram thing is an interesting tidbit, but i was curious about MAC address spoofing. can it spoof, or hide your MAC address?

for anyone who doesnt know, and actually cares.
IP address is the designation you are given by your ISP. your Internet Protocol Address.
a MAC address exists on the hardware you are using. it is like a serial number. an identity that your phone or laptop will always have no matter what it connects to, or does.
web sites and applications can see your MAC address. i know because i worked with a development team that created some site apps and had to crunch these numbers for a BI venture.
so if you are MAC address 1234 browsing my site from IP Address abcd. its not too big of a deal that you are now MAC address 1234 browsing my site from IP address wxyz. i dont target the IP address, i target the MAC address.
the only time i would want the IP address vs the MAC address would be if i was looking to measure an entire organization as a whole.
all PCs would go through a companies single IP address to a single site, as opposed to 100 MACs. so if i wanted to know what company 789 thought, i could query their IP instead of the MACs for each desktop.

VPNs are still good. they will encrypt data from your PC to the vpn host where it is then dumped into an anonymous blast of traffic to the world. so if i was a third party and wanted to sniff your specific traffic, i could only see that you browse a single sight (the vpn host) and all your data to that site is encrypted.
then it becomes a matter of trying to ascertain the content you are browsing by packet size, or time you are on the PC. some AI models are in the infancy of figuring this out, but were not really there yet.

Don't get to excited about ExpressVPN being in RAM.  It's not the end all solution.  You're information does exist, it is there.  It's just that it's life depends on a constant power state.  If a foreign government were to gain remote code execution and attack one of the many overflow vulnerabilities that exist at any given point in time they could force the servers to dump the contents of the volatile RAM to a non volatile hard disk local to them.  It's much more technical to do this here than at a company where you can just seize the servers and take your time cracking encryption.  Which brings another point, is the RAM encrypted and to what level.  If they are doing a great job encrypting they're probably doing a poor job performing and if they are doing a great job performing they are probably doing a poor job encrypting.  Nothing is really safe on the internet.  As you said in this video, it's just counter measures.  Putting data in RAM is a counter measure for the type of attacks that seize hard disks to scan logs.  It's effective at that, but new attacks will always come.

The issue many on the right have with Twitter is not that their collateral damage hits legitimate right-wing accounts. We understand that they’re trying their best to keep the platform as usable as it can be. I see no ill intentions from employees at Twitter (besides the few bad apples that, to Twitter’s credit, have been removed from the company soon after their actions have been discovered; although I don’t know whether they knew about those actions before they became public, I prefer to give benefit of the doubt until shown otherwise). However, social media companies, including Twitter, have a fatal flaw that, until fixed, will leave many right-wingers angry at the platform. The employees there may have the best intentions, and they seem to be incredibly nice and hardworking people. But, they all hold very similar viewpoints, which lean rather farther to the left. This echo chamber is what is so concerning for us on the right. I believe that Twitter should make an effort to hire people with diversity of opinions to work on their platform. This way, work can be checked by others who hold different beliefs and hold each other accountable for mistakes they might’ve missed because of their beliefs. I want left-wingers to check right-wingers, and vice versa. I think that Twitter (and other tech companies) hiring more conservative and moderate engineers and employees would go a long way to regaining trust from those not on the left.

Twitter, Facebook and in fact all social media companies have very much their own political leaning which is not entirely representative of the general population. When you use a VPN, you're trusting that VPN with the same deep level of access to your online activity that you'd normally give your ISP. In other words, now they can see what you're up to whenever you're using the internet. They might be more privacy oriented than big corporate ISP's, but they're also smaller, more opaque, and less publicly accountable. For example, who owns ExpressVPN? What government is backing it? Who has access to your data on their RAM? What government or company would benefit from publicly stating they "tried and failed" to get data and that you should "toootally trust it now"?

I hope ExpressVPN is trustworthy but not all VPNs are trustworthy. Facebook had a VPN service called Onavo that was secretly keeping track of everything you did as a means of market research. This was the period shortly before they nearly wiped Snapchat off the face of the Earth. It is likely that they were able to take Snapchat's best features because they were maliciously invading the privacy of their Onavo users. Apple found out Facebook was doing this and banned it from the App Store. Just another example of Facebook not caring about their users.

Technically, data on RAM can still be extracted shortly after a computer is turned off (from few minutes to few hours depending on the temperature and the type of memory). But it is definitely a lot harder than reading data from hard drive.

This is a very well made and informative series. I noticed a political bias on my social media feeds a few years ago and have been on and off wondering if it was a result of the demographic social media attracts, the algorithms pegging me incorrectly, or perhaps something else. I'm sure you have seen the Joe Rogan Experience with Jack Dorsey and Tim Pool, but if not, check that out! It made me realize that there was a lot more at play here than just a silicon valley company censoring right-wing topics. It brings up a lot of questions about public discourse online, and if/how it should be tailored. If a majority of people are speaking on a platform, should we avoid censorship? What if a lack of censorship means people can be harrased into abandoning the discourse entirely? Should the government be involved in checking for company bias? If so, what government has any right to regulate a global platform? This is all very interesting to me. Bottom line, I know this is not your typical kind of video series but I enjoy it thoroughly and admire the work you put into this in such a short time frame.

The story about Express VPN is not 100% correct. You cannot read any data from Random Access Memory, short RAM, if there it is not powered. So, the easiest way to deal with social media manipulation seems to be to give everyone the benefit of the doubt, but never be driven to hate another person or group of people regardless of what they do or what they believe in. Because if we stick to our morality without making exemptions for specific people just because of their behavior, then none of this would work.

Some people might think this is ignoring reality, but... media manipulation is, in a way, making you ignore reality just as much, if not more-so.

Alternatively, we could look at the world both cynically and with some optimistic sincerity. Trust people, but allow that trust to be broken if they say anything negative about anyone for any reason. If they aren't close enough for you to step aside and have a chat with them about right and wrong, then ignore them, or stop following them if nothing good comes from them again.

It would be nice if "proactive intentional unity" was an effective solution to such problems, but we're fighting against human nature itself here. On average, human nature will always win out. As a whole people are generally distrustful of outside groups, and will gravitate towards outlets that confirm their biases. Sure there are some people with natural talents and personalities that are exceptions. Some people score exceptionally high in openness, and thus more likely to seek out others not like themselves. Others just don't have an agreeable bone in them, and thus aren't as susceptible to the tactics such networks use. But these people are the exceptions. Most people aren't like that, and if you try to fight against human nature at large scale you will almost always lose.

Technically using in-memory design isn't 100% safe, especially if you consider Intel CPU have the speculative execution bug. The average person using bots isn't going to have the skills to execute an advanced attack. A skilled attacker can gain root access and have kernel level privilege. Meaning they can read memory arbitrarily if they modify the kernel. Attackers sponsored by governments or organized crime are capable of such attacks. These are old techniques dating back to 1980's. Using a VPN is still safer than not using one, but like everything software related there's always a vulnerability.

here is a story for you. Back in 2003 I worked in boston financial district building trading systems. Multiple people asked us to use social media data in trading strategies. I flat out turned denied every request pointing out how dangerous it is. Forward 2 years and I heard multiple algorithmic systems were deployed to use social media data. Soon after that, several flash crash occurred. The problem with platforms like twitter is they were designed to be insecure from the start and grafting security on after the fact makes it much more difficult. To build a secure system, you have to start from day 1. People working in information security has known this for decades, but Facebook and Twitter ignore those issues to build market share. The fight against attackers is tough, building a system to be insecure from day one makes that job several orders of magnitude harder.

isn't the difference between "attack" and "campaign" in the eye of the beholder? I mean, money scams aside, people trying to push political views on a broader public than they should are not viewing themselves as attackers. Instead they may see you as an attacker who tries to limit their freedom to communicate their political beliefs. And I purposefully use the word belief, because that is what it has currently come down to: we believe certain information, and we don't believe other. Most people don't care if it are facts, don't want to bother or spend time to check it, or don't even know the difference anymore anyway.
I think we should accept that there are moralities that are not compatible with ours, and I believe that there are ways to make us live among eachother without bothering eachother. After all, internal conflict never benefits the community. In the grand scheme of things, inhabitants of earth are a community, so in the perspective of the planet and the future, even though single actors can profit from war and conflict, the net result for the community is not benefit.
And for those who will dismiss my statement saying that it's just an unrealistic claim, I can say that I'm working on something that is not ready for release yet, but it is based on the idea that whoever understands that people are not living alone by themselves, are able to do so without conflict given the right conditions where they don't have to compromise on their personal beliefs (and views). It's a next generation system where technology is finally getting advanced enough for. It supports "national" (will have another term defined) structures in a virtual world, so that anyone can surround themself with any society they like, while functioning in a real world society where that virtual society is superposed on. I have to stay vague because I need to release it in full in order for nobody to abuse it, but I can tell that if the idea catches on, it will allow peace AND liberty to go hand in hand (which they don't right now in our current world).

The very first point, that marketing is also manipulation, is a key point. Much of the dark arts of sociopolitical manipulation owes its origins to marketing and related psychological research. Humans are easy to manipulate emotionally, and when politicians began using marketing firms it was a lot like a virus jumping from host animal to infect humans. That was the start of the appeal to the knee-jerk sentiment (we could not guard against) over rational argument.
Rupert Murdoch weaponised these techniques in the form of Fox News and News International, but his competitors were not far behind. CNN beat the war drum for over a year before the Iraq invasion. A common technique is to promote a sensational story for days, (such as the discovery of WMDs in Iraq), then issue a single retraction when the report is proven false. Even for the people who see the rectraction, the emotional payload is still in play, despite it no longer having a rational basis. This is how bias is created. (Also why Fox News has the largest viewership despite getting the worst grades on being factual.)
It was no coincidence that the deregulation of news media, the move to take news from a loss leader/public service to profitable infotainment, and granting Rupert Murdoch citizenship, all began under US President Reagan.

While I'm certainly on board with a mission to build trust rather than tear it down, the context has to be taken into account.  It's infinitely easier to trust face to face interactions compared to virtual interactions among parties that are often anonymous to you, if not literally anonymous then at least effectively anonymous.  I feel like the resolution that builds trust back into social dialog is one that abandons platforms like twitter (at least for the purposes of actual dialog) and other forms of technical convenience that can lead to message manipulation (i.e favoring long-form uncut video interviews over cut, curated, and potentially doctored interviews). Yeah... sorry again... a hacker can still get all your data even if the VPN server only runs in RAM. Which is kind of the standard way of running a non-logging server anyhow, not exactly a major technical innovation.
They can't get historical data, which is definitely a plus, but they can still record live traffic, filter it for sensitive information, and exfil it to their own server real-time.
They don't even actually need to hack the VPN server itself either, a router which handles the outgoing decrypted traffic will do, and they're often less secure.

Of course, the same goes for ISP servers and routers, so it's really just which you trust more... but still, seriously, you're doing videos trying to teach people how to avoid being manipulated by people giving misleading information for money, please stop giving people misleading information for money in them. It just makes everything else you say seem untrustworthy.

Maybe part of the problem is that a platform that limits you to 140 characters doesn't give you room to say anything subtle in any detail.

Headlines are rarely there to unify. Even when the following content is positive, The headline is usually there to be sensational and grab attention, and unfortunately, there's often not any easy way to get more (actually factual) information to form a well reasoned opinion. Most of what you'll find is either links to more social media, or to other news organizations who are reporting what they saw on social media.

People end up reading a tweet, and forming their opinions based on how that 140 characters makes them feel about whatever the subject is. Whether the content is factual or not is almost irrelevant. Even if that tweet was fake, it likely either reinforced your ideas, or further vilified the other side. When you realize it was "fake news", can you actually disregard it on an emotional level, or are you still angry about whatever the other side could have done, even if it's not real?

I really wish we could understand each other better. While there are all sorts of points of view people like to break things down into a binary political system and then try to separate each side. For better or worse we usually use the terms conservative and liberal, but for the moment I will call them preservers and revisers. The preservers try to keep the system working so that we aren’t living in chaos. The revisers see problems in the system and try to change it so the system works better so we can have a better future. Most of us would fall somewhere in the middle; we want to keep what we like and change what we don’t like (most real politics negotiates the balance at this point), but people like to push us out of this middle area where we can find common ground and move us off to each side and then paint each extreme in the worst possible way to the opposite side. According to those sewing division, conservatives resist change so they can keep their position of privilege so they can keep oppressing minorities and women, and liberals want to take all your money and give it to those who don’t deserve it and to destroy everything that’s dear. And of course there are many worse things, but the point isn’t to dwell on those because while there are definitely people at the extremes, they are actually very few, but most of us in the middle have more in common with each other than those extreme edge cases in either side.

Destin, I think you missed out on one of the coolest aspects of all this electronic warfare between Twitter and the bots. Alan Turing is considered by many to be the father of modern computer science. He invented the stored-program computer and the "universal Turing machine" that is still taught in some college computer science courses. He was also keenly interested in the human brain and how thinking occurred and whether it could be reproduced with a machine.


He proposed what is now called the "Turing Test" of artificial intelligence. In this test a human subject is placed in a room with nothing but a keyboard and monitor. Outside the room is either another keyboard and monitor manned by a real person or a computer attempting to simulate a real person. The human subject interacts with the other human or computer in any way desired. They can ask questions, make jokes, etc. After an hour or so the human subject is asked if they were talking to a real human or a computer or if they were unable to decide. The objective of the AI program in the computer is to fool the human subject into thinking they are dealing with a real human and not a machine. The success of the AI program can be quantified by the number of human subjects it was able to fool.

The bots attacking Twitter and Youtube are attempting to mimic real humans in order to get past Twitter's filters. Twitter's countermeasures are attempting to decide if the person creating an account is a real person or a bot. Basically, they are engaging in an ongoing Turing Test on a grand scale. It's millions of Turing Tests per day. It's a Turing Test between commercial enterprises, not academic researchers. It's a Turing Test with real money at stake and real social consequences.


I appreciate that your videos focus on the human aspect of this and the tribalism it fosters but the from the pure 100% geek standpoint the Turing Test angle is fascinating. Some grad student somewhere should write a dissertation on this.

One very known and most effective method that some of those malicious people use, is by actually "hacking" into other people's devices and using them as "bots". So the activity (likes, comments..etc) actually come from real people. How often do you check your history? have you ever notice a post you did not make?
I know this, because I have been on both sides, I have hacked into things and I'm also admin on many websites and systems where I have to counter such hacks.

For example most effective way of sending anonymous email, is to "steal" someone's account and use that account to send the email, then delete this email from victim's sent mails and block the email (where you sent the anonymous email to) so that the person can't reply back. This way email is authentic, yet it cannot be traced back to the original source and owner of the stolen account (victim) would not even be aware of it, he/she can still use the account and doesn't realize that his/her account was (or still is) being used for sending out anonymous emails.

This "trick" works on all platforms really. On PC it gets bit harder if you know what you're doing, but on phone it's quite easy to make someone fall for something that takes control of your phone and uses it as a bot to send out those manipulative posts / emails ..etc.

BOTTOM LINE - those things exists, because of people's stupidity and desire to use scam to get ahead of others! If there would be nobody out there who's willing to buy those services to boost their accounts, then there would really be no need for that and if people would not be stupid enough to fall for those things (not clicking on random links on emails, not downloading random garbage..etc), then those attackers couldn't really use those methods.

The very human urge to create in and out groups (us and them mentality) is a very interesting problem, especially in a world where the average person rarely has 'enemies' who are actively trying to harm them.
If you study this problem and come to the conclusion that this mentality is inevitable to some degree, then the best solution would be to try to get the snake to devour itself, by making the 'enemy' group for as many people as possible any actors who are trying to magnify that effect and perhaps aim it maliciously.
The most important step then would be to make the mentality or desires that are leading to this behavior the enemy, rather than the people that hold them, so that the only course of action for people who hear and believe your message is to engage in intellectual, educational and compassionate pursuits, since anything else would damage their in-group: human individuals.


Not necessarily saying that that is what's happening here, but I've noticed a number of people whose ideas could be interpreted this way, and I've also noticed that I can't stand people who attack anything other than divisive, harmful ideas.

The explanation of using RAM for security is laughable. The memory hierarchy provides no intrinsic security at all.
The only sure-fire way for your data to be secure is to partake in E2E encryption.

Although it is true that it could not be seized, it is not `unhackable`. Actively monitoring their servers and taking memory-dumps would be enough to obtain all user traffic, which is not implausible for targeted attacks or for any mass-surveillance schemes.

so, in the interest of being independent-minded... how sure are we that twitter - as a corporation - isn't manipulating the trends with some of their own ulterior motives?

their engineers have the "perfect excuse" to avoid talking specifics: don't wanna leak intel to the "enemy" in an arms race. but this is also great cover if there are certain interpretations of their ToS which disadvantages certain types of accounts or political posts.

for example, the alt-right personalities who rail non-stop that they're being shadow-banned because of their right-wing sensibilities... 1) it is quite difficult for us users to even notice discrete examples of this phenomenon, let alone prove it, 2) it's even harder to prove there's coordinated action against a particular movement, 3) even if some reasonable level of suspicion can be established, twitter can easily parry these allegations as "false positives" without ever going into detail about anything because "need to stay ahead in the arms race".

due to the secrecy surrounding the management of social media, the corporation itself could apply manipulative techniques for their own benefit - and there could be no way for third-party observers (and/or users) to ever definitively identify that. in fact, it should be easiest for the platform itself to manipulate the popular narrative for their own benefit, since the only way such things could leak would be via whistleblowers. meanwhile, this allegation itself is also very clearly conspiracy-theory-like... since we have no positive evidence and just a lot of educated guessing and doubts.

if social media platforms are run by private companies and they are allowed to operate like an intelligence agency; but without any electoral oversight in any way, shape or form... something just feels really wrong with the picture. who's accountable to whom? when @realDonaldTrump posts a ridiculous tweet... some of us lol and move on; but others may be forced to make foreign policy adjustments, redirect sizable financial investments, or get ready for (yet another) hellish thanksgiving. whether we like it or not, these "beautiful things" have oversized real-world impact - specifically regarding how a democracy functions - but they are only accountable to their shareholders (at best).

Regarding what you say at 24:45 about choosing not to trust, there is an old statement that's in line with your previous video in the series, "Trust, but verify". I trust my father, but I've caught him being wrong, so I double check what he says IF it happens to matter. I trust my peers, but I verify what they say IF it happens to matter. By the same token, I trust your videos, but I verify IF it happens to matter.


That said, there is reason not to trust too, though. The people I have the option to vote for, I do NOT trust because I have reason to believe they are all malicious actors, though sadly not foreign. In 2012, for example, we had the infamous Todd Akin running against Claire McCaskill, which went from a certain Republican win after her callous treatment of voters to her victory after he said something insane. It was revealed at the time that she had donated to his primary campaign, but she has since bragged about her pied-piper strategy that got him through the primary. This was remarkable in that it was so out in the open and blatant, but this is politics as usual. And there is no "local" exemption to this - we've had governors, mayors, sheriffs, and county clerks do very illegal things because they thought they could get away with it, use intentionally divisive language to prey on people's fears, and openly act to harm the people who elected them in blatant disregard for their campaign promises.


I used to trust media. That's a trust, though, that was legitimately lost outside of Twitter's sphere of influence. The unverified story to news pipeline has been increasingly harmful, as has been the clear but unstated agendas of the various networks. But the real loss of trust has been with the clear psychological manipulation through hate and anger. This started becoming a problem in the 90's with political "shock jocks" who intentionally went beyond the pale to get people to listen in so that they could know what they were supposed to be upset about. It expanded into television "news" where news networks would set aside ever-growing blocks of time where news-like presentations were given by intentionally offensive personalities. Online, it has manifested in the form of "bad takes" that have people clicking the article more to find out who the author is and if there's a comments section than to actually read the article. And, sadly, local news is not exempt from bad practices. The "retraction on page 10" yellow journalism strategy never truly went away, but it gains new life in agenda-driven journalism that runs hit pieces on people associated with the politician it wants to hurt...then buries the retraction.


I know it's controversial, but this also extends to local businesses whose marketing campaigns rely on copyright infringement, misleading phrasing, abuse of audio compression, and then an appeal to their alleged impact on the local community (which, at least here, is worse than Walmart's).


Even if foreign actors are preying on it, the distrust was locally grown. While my examples only span my lifetime, people have held distrust of these things for centuries, and never without reason. You'll probably recognize some of the terms I used are so old they squeezed fresh dinosaur for their gas back when the terms were coined. Social media explodes the scale and impact of these problems, but the problems won't go away just by tweaking algorithms. A sea change is needed before we can insist on the value of trust.

@Destin I love the channel and all the things you’re teaching me. Thinking about the human behaviour factors, check out the topic behavioural biometrics and how banks are using it to stop fraud. Specifically, check out a company called BioCatch who are leaders in this space.

VPNs aren't bad, but you and they are horribly misrepresenting what they can do for their users.

The problem isn't that the VPN service has your data instead of the ISP--which really is just shifting whom you trust from one uncontrollable actor to another (whatever they /say/ they do, verifiably did in the past, etc.)--it's that every service and site with whom you interact does (VPN or not). More importantly, it's that most of the time this doesn't mean the sites themselves but rather the many affiliated services /they/ use (like ad networks, social networks, analytics platforms, etcetera) and even malicious code that manages to compromise any of these non-security-focused platforms. Most of the information they can and do collect was never vulnerable to disclosure in transit to begin with because it was already encrypted (assuming it mattered and no one was making the kind of obvious mistakes that get professionals fired). VPNs aren't useless, but their use-cases mostly revolve around avoiding being physically tracked down by actors with some but not all of the resources to do so. Remaining truly anonymous (if that's your aim) requires more care, paranoia, and resources than most people can reasonably hope to accomplish, and a VPN offers one tiny fragment of that recipe that's little use on its own.

In short, stop worrying about who's listening into the conversation when it's the /intended audience/ that's compromising your privacy. Privacy experts weren't really able to predict how innocuous metadata about your activity could prove distinct enough to uniquely profile you in such a distributed manner, nor that any actors would be able to gather enough of it to compile such profiles. This is why they focused on educating us about transport layer security despite that only being an issue when obvious mistakes are being made. Worrying about whether someone can get access to your bank account or credit card as you bank or shop online is fighting yesterday's battles. (The short answer is they can't, the medium answer is that your biggest threat is still shoulder surfers followed by entering such data on malware-infected computers, and the long answer is too long for this medium). Even worrying about actors with direct trunk-line access that are bad or vulnerable to abuse (like the NSA) is a bit like trying to protect yourself from Russian nukes. Your bunkers may not hurt, but it's a very long shot that they'll ever help anyone besides the peddlers of bunker rations.

LOL Twitter GTA RP. Good to see the internet freaks are still at it. Also, yes you should not trust anything anyone says if you can't verify and they can't provide adequate evidence. That line of thinking does not mean you don't treat your friends and neighbors with respect. A default of suspicion is helpful for everyone acting honestly. The practice is similar to how scientists come to consensus on topics.


For example, I have a friend that regularly parrots things they have heard or read that turns out to be a less than honest evaluation of the topic. When I'm suspicious of the friends evaluation I try to explain that I will have to do some research of my own and ask for any sources that relate to their viewpoint. I then make a point to set aside time for looking into the topic before I next meet with the friend. Sometimes what they say turns out to be a fairly matter of fact explanation that ends up being useful for me as I now am aware of something. Most of the time there is a lot of bias that has to be parsed, and whatever is the topic ends up to have been a less than honest evaluation of information.

What is light?

Light is energy, energy must coexist with matter. There is no light in the space between hot plasma on the Sun and atmosphere on Earth.

All scientists thought light is EM wave or photon particle or both traveling in space at light speed. They are all wrong. There is no wave, no photon, nothing traveling in space at light speed. Energy teleport from matter to matter instantly, becomes light wave traveling in medium at light speed. Light speed in vacuum space is infinite. Therefore, cosmology, relativity, QM and electromagnetism are all wrong.

By using MIT 10 trillion frame per second high speed camera, scientists can measure light speed in a vacuum glass bottle to prove light speed in vacuum is infinite. But they won't do it, because if the truth is out, they will be in big trouble.

Electromagnetic Radiation

Electrons are on the surface of all matters. Electrons are constantly vibrating due to the thermal energy atoms carried. The higher temperature the higher vibration frequency.

Vibrating electrons carry kinetic energy, that energy can transfer to distant electrons through the repulsion force between line of sight electrons F=Ke x ee/R^2, science call it electromagnetic radiation. In Fact, there is only electrostatic radiation, there is no electromagnetic radiation.

How to prove it?

Electrostatic force decays at 1/R^2, light wave strength decays at 1/R^2, Magnetic force decays at 1/R^3.

Photoelectric effect is misinterpretation. Light wave energy density is proportional to frequency. When light wave frequency is high enough, electrons will be vibrating out from solar cell.

There is no photon particle impact electron and knock it out from atoms.

That's why Einstein said he knows NOT what are light quanta. Everyone thinks he knows it is mistaken.

The first person to do a double slit experiment in vacuum, prove there is no light wave in vacuum space, can win a Nobel and change the history.

If you have the access, you should take this unique opportunity.

Put the slits and screen on the walls of a square glass container. Point a laser beam on the slits, video the light wave interference on the screen. Then vacuum the container, video the interference disappear and left two bright lines on the screen as if light act as particle.

In fact, light is not wave nor particle, light is vibrating electrostatic force carry by vibrating electrons/atoms.

Please make sure the slits and the screen are on the inside of the container walls. Nothing is between the slits and screen. No air, no glass, only empty space.

Ok, I am going to level with you, and I'd like your thoughts. This video is making me self-reflect. I study advertising, I have specialised in behaviour change. I own a business where we creatively apply behavioural science (behavioural economics) to influence behaviour. Literally, on my bed right now I have a book titled Hooked: how to build habit forming products. I've got more into network analysis recently: target the influencers. I should point out, 99% of the time, users benefit. Ie, an experience becomes less effortful, more rewarding.


Q: where do you draw the line of what is and isn't ok? My personal view is to consider if I'm ok with the ends: the end behaviour. The means are less important. For example, I don't feel bad about designing interventions to make carrying a condom or using a fitness app a more habitual behaviour. Whether I achieved that through fancy psychology or a simple poster campaign is kinda irrelevant. The key thing is whether the end behaviour is ok to increase or decrease.

This is frustratingly complex. Say we take an active stance toward unification. We will still naturally align in similar thinking "tribes". The left and the right won't settle their differences by way of offering each other grace on twitter when someone says something divisive. We do no see eye to eye on authoritarianism, we don't see eye to eye on abortion, social safety nets and the very concept of free speech. The left could easily say "We're trying to unite everyone through progress! Why aren't you joining us in uniting?" but if you at a base level disagree with their world view, you can't simply deny your own values for the sake of unity. Grace and efforst toward Unity do nothing.

Realistically we need open dialog and less viewing of each other as enemies. We need real tolerance, not the phony kind that is only skin deep. Two people need to look each other in the eye, one says I like our president and the other says I hate our president, and they are ok with that and go have a beer or throw a frisbee. THAT's what we need if we want to get out of this problem. We need to be ok with not being unified while simultaneously rejecting tribalism. We need a revolution of individualism.

I see so many tech startups who deliver inexpensive solutions but the cost savings is typically a result of an inability to police their service. Look at telecom in the United States compared to Twitter for example. Your local telephone service is very trustworthy and reliable because of strict regulation and policing. Sure there are stories of infamous telco hackers but they are practically zero when compared to the millions of attacks on Twitter every week. The internet is still the wild west and services that rely on it will never be able to be fully policed or trustworthy unless they are designed from the ground up with integrity in mind, and they invest in the resources required to be effective.
I think this is difficult for Americans to understand how untrustworthy online platforms are because of how most services were regulated throughout the 20th century. Consider advertising for example. The FTC has strict control over print advertising and has for decades but now with the internet there are rampant violations in online advertising and the FTC simply cannot handle it all.

Once you login to a website most of the protection that a VPN provides is nullified. Most websites will give your data to the advertisers on their website so they can get more $ from each view/click. Social media is a constant source of inaccurate information which is often created and spread by people who benefit from that information. An algorithm isn't going to be able to adapt fast enough to prevent being manipulated. However, a human can. So, what if we could subscribe to social media curators. For example, I know John Doe is trust worthy and does his research. If I trust John Doe then I can subscribe and only content John Doe has curated will appear in my news feed and recommendations. I'm still seeing the original creators work and the original creator still gets paid his ad revenue, but the curator is also paid a small contribution. This way we can build trust with a small number of curators and not have to research ever single content creator which is just unrealistic.

How this would work - create a new role in youtube called a Curator who you can subscribe to. Then the only the curator's recommendations would appear in your news feed. Obviously, if you are subscribed to more then one curator then your news feed would be a mix of the two or more.

Benefit - Curators have incentive to approve advertiser friendly content and advertisers can build relationships with curators.

Known issue - This could create echo chambers, but I think their may be ways to create incentives to prevent this.

I'm sure you will get other comments about this, but I will say it anyway to boost the signal in the noise:
Using volatile memory does not guarantee no one can extract it. As you say, it means the data is lost when eg power is lost. If the system is accessed while your data is there, it can be extracted. Many of the more secure software used today by consumers, such as password managers, are susceptible to RAM attacks where they extract data from RAM directly.


That said, it does make the data much less permanent so it is an interesting choice and I believe probably a good one.

I know engineers at a lot of these big places like FB, Google, and Twitter... they're really smart and trying to solve really complex problems, but trying to think in terms of world politics or ill-intentioned nation states is almost maddening. It's challenging enough trying to balance the real needs of human beings whose lives are impacted by the software you develop — but then trying to anticipate what impact the features you build out or the design choices you make might have on, say, the democratic uprising Arab Spring or the Kremlin's propaganda campaign during annexation of the Ukraine. The deeper your understanding of the technology, the clearer your understanding of what's ethical and what's not, for that technology — but there's also the harsh political reality that if you discover or call attention to these problems, you're likely to become the scapegoat for a negligent organization.

I know how difficult it is to act with integrity in those moments, so I appreciate you shining light into this part of the web. The only hesitation I have with a "we should all be unified" message is that it puts the onus on people who largely don't even realize how or the degree to which they're being manipulated. I’m a huge proponent of forgiveness and grace. I'm a Christ-follower and care a great deal about those things! But what I'm seeing among many of my friends (on the left and on the right) is cynicism and apathy masquerading as unity. (e.g. “I'll just stay off Facebook because I can’t trust anyone” or “anyone who disagrees with me must be a bot and not worth my time engaging”.) Almost like a DDOS attack for human minds—and that's something that unity won't necessarily fix (though it will certainly lessen/slow the damage) and will continue to be a problem until we can figure out a way to address the underlying flaws and unhealthy incentives in our platforms.

Anyhow, thank you so much for tackling this important topic, Destin. I appreciate your time, your video, and your service to our country. I've been a fan of your videos since you shot rockets at a brush pile. My family watches them regularly. Thanks for getting my son excited about science (he wants to be an electrical engineer).
